comments.body: I would also like to find archaeological artifacts and loot when brushing sand near desert wells.
Doesn't even have to be caves if thats too much, something like a guaranteed geode, or a larger than usual pocket of ore would be awesome
yes! And the caves under desert well should be at least partially submerged.

I think this is a great idea! Since the azaleas are not going to be a new kind of tree, I think it is important to note that there is relatively little chance for them to spawn in desserts so if we can have a good indicator of lush caves in the form of the dessert well, that would be brilliant!

I agree, but caves in general aren't uncommon for it to need a structure to signify it. It should only be 1 cave type, & in my opinion lush caves don't fit. It would be a much better idea for it to signify dripstone caves, because 1: We already have a signifier for lush caves in normal biomes, but not for dripstone caves. 2: It fits with the lore of underground people once getting their water only from the dripstone, especially in the dry desert, & the water in the desert well is some of it.
caves in deserts should generate with sandstone, but only above y=0
I think this is a great idea. Every time I see one (in creative mode at least) I look under it.
love it! it would be so cool! (i always thought if you saw a dessert well you where bye a village)
Good idea, but instead of a desert cave, I think it should indicate a lush cave under a desert biome. I mean, it doesn't make much sense if you find an azalea tree in the middle of desert.

I think this is a great idea, I was trying to build something that this would be super useful for today!
Specifically, this would make fully automatic laca farms possible when combined with the new dripstone mechanic, and for what I was doing, you'd have a block that stores a readable redstone signal that also can be changed by dispensers and pushed by pistons. This would make it possible to create a Turing machine (fundamental functions of a computer!) In an extremely compact and intuitive way. Technically you can already make a redstone device that does this in a different way but it's much more complex to do so.
and for potions in cauldrons, it should only work with empty bottles!
The fact that this isn't a feature drives me insane, you can use a dispenser to place lava/water in air so why not pick and place in a cauldron too. This needs to be added

I was building a cobblestone generator that doubled as a lava farm. And was trying to connect it to my smelter build a piston feed tape of cauldrons item elevators to my auto smelter. Went to build a dispenser to pick up the lava from the cauldrons... Found out it didn't work googled how to make it work and ended up here 4 hours shot just like that

I really really wish this was able to be done in bedrock or java. You can pick up water or lava with a bucket in a dispenser...but not from a cauldron? Why? One of those bits of functionalities that should have been added years ago...
That's a very very much needed feature!!!!!!
see also https://feedback.minecraft.net/hc/en-us/community/posts/10130085941773-Dispensers-should-be-able-to-pickup-lava-water-from-cauldrons?page=1#community_comment_25073787256205

In addition to dispensers being able to place and remove lava normally, they can also shear sheep and collect honey from beehives, which for the latter in particular, feels like it'd be near identical to what it'd be like mechanically with cauldrons.

Hello this thing has already been made go here if you want help move it forward https://feedback.minecraft.net/hc/en-us/community/posts/360040224391-Building-on-top-of-the-nether also it already has over 2500 votes so that may be a better use of your time.
Yes it because some things from tutorials aren't possible without building on the nether roof.
Thats exactly waht we need
Yes I’ve been wanting this to happen forever if only we had like 100,000 people to vote for this, ut would be awesome
I hate building a farm and they half way through realise its for java, and i didnt know u couldnt build on the nether roof, i was realy disapointed.
yes everyone hates having to traverse the annoying terain is servival and for noobs they would try to do this and be stick pleas change that
If you right click a chain on two touching minecarts, maybe they'd connect.
yes, please

Great idea I think if u could they should use chains and it could use simarlar code to leads
Also I think that they should add furnace Minecarts so u can get that train feeling ik u can use power rails but it makes sense cuz u have to continueasly pay coal to keep it moving some people would love the idea

you can kind of link minecarts with a furnace minecart (but it only works on flat and straights) i just completed a giant bridge on my survival world with a furnace minecart and its pretty cool, though i wish i wouldn't have to purposely shove my 2nd base to a really far distance to justify its use. (it would be awesome to link them together :(

Now that they added the ability to link 2 or more entities (animals, happy ghast, and boat) with a leash, a similar mechanic can be added with minecarts, but they can only be linked together with a chain and it would be something similar to a train but with minecarts.
I would say they should have a 20% chance of doing nothing, but the rest is a very good and unique idea.

399754911932 The issue with that is that it would allow you to just continue eating glowberries on and on and you would get a continued night vision effect, which would be a bit overpowered in my opinion.  The chance of blindness adds a little risk factor and also implements a natural cooldown of sorts.  Plus, it would just be much more interesting.
The amount of time it takes should be less than ten seconds I think.

In the official suggestion of glow berries from 2019, it says glowing effect. I think a 40% chance of getting the glowing effect, %30 chance of getting getting night vision, 20% chance of getting none of the effects and 10% of getting both effects would be cool.
If we eat glow berries then it shall give 19 seconds of night vision effect

365331690731 I don't think guaranteed night vision would be unbalanced, since you'd have to constantly eat glow berries for constant night vision which would slow down movement significantly and would drain your glow berry supply pretty fast.
They are too easy to farm. Maybe a 1 percent chance.
I literally thought of this idea while playing the snapshot, and just looking at the inventory
ChipsNachos you wouldn't be able to eat them nonstop because you can't eat once your hunger bar is full (unless that is exclusive to bedrock).
I just wanted to write the same thing, it’s a great idea. You read my mind.
i think it should just give you night vision for 5 seconds and the glowing effect for 5 seconds as well.
glow berries only restore one heart so i think this is a great idea! but not for blindness.

Adding to this idea, I think all stone types in general should have more parity in terms of variants. Why do we have stone bricks and not andesite bricks, or what happened with chiseled granite. This is of course applies to the new stones as well.
Tuff should also be more brownish just like real-life. This would be a great addition!
Dont forget Calcite
I think that it would be nice to see a polished form of them too as well as calcite equivalents (along with slab, stair and wall variants).
Polished Tuff and Calcite whould be great too but I guess the Calcite will look way to similar to Granite but yea

This is a excellent idea! Tuff is a stone type of course so It makes sense that it would be able to be crafted or cut into bricks. It should also be able to be crafted/cut into Tuff stairs, Tuff walls, and Tuff slabs. And It should be able to be crafted/cut into the Tuff bricks, Tuff brick stairs, Tuff brick wall, and Tuff brick slabs. And all of the Tuff variants should be able to be polished (Polished Tuff bricks/ Polished tuff). Another great idea for Tuff is that it could possibly be used to make stronger pistons as well, The "Tuff pistons" could be used to push more blocks (credit for ''Tuff piston'' idea goes to Mumbo jumbo). I think that the tuff block has a lot of potential so please tell me what you think, Thank you.
I think this would be cool but the grimstone bricks look kinda what this would look like & there should also be calcite bricks
I like this! I think there should also be polished dripstone and chiseled dripstone.
Tuff bricks should also be used in many of the buildings in the deep dark, if there are any buildings other than just chests.
Tuff bricks are going to be added, it will spawn in trial chambers.

yeah i think this idea is great but i also think people are too hung up on the idea the netherite can't be better than diamond except durability, and diamond has to be the best tier in terms of capabilities
I love this idea. :)
Need this badly
We need this asap
The addition of deepslate has affected the game negatively for me because diamonds are exceedingly sparse, and deepslate is slow to mine.
This is very much needed, since gathering large amounts of deepslate is painful, and it would be a good way to further differentiate diamond from netherite gear.
yes, either that or introduce some endgame way to activate haste III for beacons.
This the idea i was just about to add so have voted for this. This would be good as you have to work upto enchments nethrite and a beacon.
interesting and definitely a needed concept. maybe the lumberjack can sell things such noteblocks or jukeboxes, since they require wood to make. Or even petrified wood and its variants.

Actually I'm not against wood or sapling trades, but it would be pretty sad to get only 10 for 1 emerald. Since wood's really common, 1 emerald for a stack of saplings & 1 emerald for 24 wood(& stripped wood) wouldn't be bad, especially if you are in the early game or have an emerald farm. But there could be other useful things to trade with. What if Lumberjacks could sell wood carvings of MC mobs? That would be really cool. That's the only way you would get them. Lumberjacks are more experienced with wood than the others, so they could have custom wood items like that. And since you can't un-craft wood items, maybe trading emeralds would give you a lot more fences, slabs, & stairs than you would get with trading normal wood. Maybe you would get a stack and a half of fences or slabs for an emerald. Yes that's cheap, but so is wood itself. Anything lower than that might not be worth trading with.

You would give the lumberjack wood and saplings for emeralds because villagers receive raw materials and give finished products. Also getting 24 wood would be so unbalanced that no one would ever chop down trees again, and you can craft them into sticks to trade with a flecther and get an infinite profit.

My son and I were just talking over a similar idea. Lumberjack/woodcutter/carpenter villager could buy/sell logs and planks at low levels and level up to signs, fences, axes, and rarer woods. Maybe even throw stripped logs in the mix somewhere.

I think you're thinking too small. Why stop at wood stairs and slabs? It could also be used to craft fences and fence gates with a 1:1 ratio, the same way you can make walls with a stonecutter. As it stands, you end up losing a plank (more if you count sticks as half a plank) when you craft fences or gates. It could also be used for trapdoors, which currently require six planks for just two trapdoors, and maybe even regular doors as well.

I also don't see much of a problem with a villager type that sells wood. As someone who uses a lot of wood, it's pretty hard to get enough of it without a large-scale tree farm. There are villagers you can buy food from, which hardly anyone is going to do, but it's an option. Buying wood from a villager would just be another option for how to get it.
I really think the wood should get it's counterpart like stone. If there is a ever a lumberjack villager (which should exist tbh), I hope he can have a varied inventory like masons or shepherds.

A woodcutter/sawmill is a great idea and is absolutely necessary for Minecraft. The stonecutter makes building with stone much more efficient and cost-effective than building with wood. A crafting station that would allow wood planks to be instantly converted to stairs, slabs, and even fences would be incredibly useful and not at all overpowered, as this is something players can already do with stone. There is absolutely no reason stone blocks should get this privilege and not wood blocks. This should be equalized and a woodcutter/sawmill should be added to the game. As for a lumberjack villager, I think this is a very interesting proposition, but honestly, if a woodcutter/sawmill is added to the game I would be ecstatic.

I really miss a woodcutter with a similar function as a stone cutter. For me, it doesn't even need to be a workstation for a villager, at least not at the beginning, but could be similar to the crafting table. Or the crafting table, which already looks like a workbench, could be upgraded using some metal / ore to include woodcuter functionality. It could be balanced in a way that you need to start with logs or planks and it makes items crafted with sticks more expensive than crafting them by hand while making items such as stairs cheaper and making all items individually craftable (e.g. 1 door = 2 planks).

I still like the idea of a lumberjack villager too - but this is secondary to a woodcutter for me. I like the trading ideas of the lumberjack buying quite a bit of wood / saplings for emeralds and selling crafted items. I can also imagine the lumberjack working similar to a farmer and roaming around a certain distance from the workstation to cut down trees.
I really wish this would come into play. Big projects with wood really leech wood reserves when crafting things like stairs and fences.
This is a no brainier. I'm constantly annoyed by needing 1 block for 1 stair in a stonecutter and then 6 for 4 in a crafting table. This needs more attention

I think the sawmill should be crafted with copper and iron. And it could be very useful for making not only stairs, but also doors, trapdoors, fences, fence gates, and maybe wood tools. It could strip wood as well, saving your axe's durability.

As for the Lumberjack villager, they could buy various saplings and axes. They can sell logs and planks at level 1. But at higher levels, they can start selling leaves, 6-sided wood blocks, and even charcoal.

I saw a mod for this awhile ago and I have to say having a sawmill would be fantastic! it would conserve so much resources and you know maybe it could contain a few new recipes too! for instance the bamboo mosaic block? why not have like a type of decorational block like that! it could only be crafted in a sawmill! I would love to see a Lumberjack villager too! maybe he could trade stuff like sticks for emeralds like the fletcher but have another chance to trade saplings for emerald too I mean every lumberjack needs to repopulate the cutdown trees right? In addition to those you could trade him emeralds for axes much like the weapon smith and maybe iron for emeralds? then in return these lumberjacks will be biome dependant too so they will have wood trades depending on the biomes they are closest too so for instance a spruce village next to a roofed forest and birch forest could have trades like birch logs for emeralds or even spruce logs for emeralds!

The more I play, the more I want this feature.
My only comment is that the work station would be for a *carpenter* profession; not a lumberjack.
Lumberjacks chop trees, carpenters make things out of wood.
So the trades wouldn't be wood or saplings, they would be finished would products like trap doors and fences.

When it drips water/lava, but if there is no Cauldron under then it should slowly form a stalagmite under that spike and it would have phases, until it became a full one. This makes sense because water/lava would take some of the material from above and bring it down. this would be cool too have inside the game.

I feel the lava/water filling times for the cauldron can be a little long, and can maybe be increased a little bit. We don’t want it to be too fast though, or else it will make it too easy to get infinite lava.
The drip stone doesn't look blocky (or just doesn't feels like minecraft) and infinite lava is just messed up
Lava should fill cauldrons much faster in the Nether, because in the Nether lava flows faster.
When dripstone falls on anything or is broken, it should not drop anything. This is because dripstone is fragile; if you used Silk Touch on it, they will drop stalactites or stalagmites.

I kind of hate how they look. 2d pillars just don't look right for minecraft. There's a mod that does stalagmites and stalactites really well, and I bet if you just got in contact with the author he/she would be happy to let you use them, provided credit is given.

Lava should be in layers. I'm not saying they should be collected in bottles, but lava should be layered.

In rain, cauldrons should also collect water. (Edit: Sorry, I didn't know this was already a feature. Just ignore this :D)

Finally, stalagmites and especially stalactites should deal double the damage currently in the game (4hp/meter of falling)

The texture seemed a little wonky to me at first, but after playing the 20w48a snapshot i easily got used to it, no texture change neccesary. Other than that, good work!

This comment is similar to 392287373031's comment . My idea is that when there is a water source block above a dripstone block stalactite must form under it , and if there is another dripstone block about    5 - 10 blocks below a stalagmite must form on top of it .
When you're wearing boots, fall damage from landing on stalagmites should be reduced. This would be consistent with helmets protecting against falling stalactites.

Cauldrons should fill up with water from stalactites much faster. Renewable water is pretty easy to get anyways, so having stalactites be a way to instead get water quickly would make them a viable alternative.
I'll add these to mine and everyone's PS4 and console right now!
3,2,1, and finished!<:)!
The damage done by them should increase with velocity.
Currently, I think dripstone is pretty balanced, but I think that bigger stalactites should deal more damage than small ones.

They might already have this feature, but dripstone should generate naturally inside underwater cave systems as well as in open air.

It just looks weird for underwater caves/underground lakes to have completely smooth floors, and irl underwater caves/ underground lakes are choked with stalagmites.

Imagine how cool it would be to swim around unimaginably tall dripstone pillars in a pitch-black, bottomless underground lake, the dripstone emerging from the abyss for who knows how far, traversing underwater corridors and labyrinths of stalagmites..

I know that this isn't one of the questions but I know a lot of people feel this way. I think that you should make the dripstone itself look better, right now it looks like a weird x but I think it should be more 3d similar to the end rod.
It might be a bit of a wildcard, but I'd like to see dripstone slabs, stairs and wall. I think it would really expand the amount of options builders have when using those variant blocks.

there should be another variant of dripstone  

there could be icicles that act similar to drip stone but only able to be places on ceilings and they can only drip water
I think it's cool
The other stone blocks should get pointed variants (stalagmites and stalactites).
There needs to be dripstone bricks, polished dripstone, and all those kinds of variants for dripstone.

Dripstone does not have a minecraft look at all.  This changes the feel and look of the game, it's built like a plant but it's a block.  but it's not a block, its a point...

Also, the prevalance of dripstone is wildly random in these caves.  It looks 'painted on' to the other block textures instead of looking like it flows from the other blocks  Perhaps the dripstone blocks needs a bit more Stone texture/color to it to help it blend,

I think that steping or walking on them should not deal to much damage; maybe half a heart 50% of the times. Falling on them could be affected by feather falling enchantment or/and from the material of the boots.

Same for the falling dripstone. Wearing a helmet could reduce the damage taken a little. Bigger stalactites could deal slitely more damage. Stalactites previously hanging under lava could set the player on fire for a second. Also adjasoned stalactites could be trigered in rare ocasions.

Abou the filling speed. It does feel slow. Maybe more particles should be shown so players know that they did it right. Also the distance between cauldron and dripstone should affect the rate.

Eu achei essa atualização muito boa mas o bloco de dripstone está faltando sem ele não podemos gerar a dripstone mais fácil. Tambem eu acho que a dripstone tenho um processo de enchimento dos caldeirões com lava ou água muito demorado poderia encurtar um pouco este processo.

I found this update very good but the dripstone block is missing without it we can't generate the dripstone easier. Also I think that the dripstone i have a process of filling the cauldrons with lava or very time consuming water could shorten this process a little.

The lava should fill in levels instead of all at once. It would be a good way to slow it down and also add an "animation". Dripstone should create more dripstone if there isn't a cauldron underneath it.
We need a gamerule or other way to prevent trident from destroying pointed dripstone
Damage should increase with velocity
Stepping ir walking on them should just be slower to indicate the careful traversing of them
I think the stalagmites and stalactites look really weird imo. I think if they were more blocky than 2d like fire, they'd look better.

If there is not going to be any other tan-tinted stone, I would suggest dripstone bricks, polished dripstone, etc to give us a nice muted warm-palette of bricks to work with. Though I feel that a muted-tan stone type would be cool as a standalone feature, if there's no intention to add something like that, I think dripstone would work perfectly.

Dripstones need a retexture. Currently, when you generate a Dripstone world, they look really ugly. The dripstone block doesn't blend well with stone. Making the dripstone block smoother would fix this.

I agree with these two comments above:

1. When dripstone falls on anything or is broken, it should not drop anything. This is because dripstone is fragile; if you used Silk Touch on it, they will drop stalactites or stalagmites. (commented by Isaac Annear)

2. When it drips water/lava, but if there is no Cauldron under then it should slowly form a stalagmite under that spike and it would have phases, until it became a full one. (commented by by CurvedCrib13)

The first idea is about Dripstone shouldn't be too easy to get, and the second idea is about Dripstone should be a renewable resource that is able to farm it (by waterdrop), and I think it will be great and balanced if these two ideas are combined.

I think that Dripstone's texture is ugly and doesn't blend well with stone blocks around, and I guess many other people think that's awkward too.

That's because stalactites and stalagmites are usually found in limestone caves in the real world. Therefore, users feel that the classic Stone blocks are not fit in.

So Limestone block should be added and replace Stone block in the Dripstone Cave biome to make it looks beautiful and natural.

a nice mechanic to add would be that explosions made some of the stalactites in the cave fall down because of the shockwave since IRL they are quite fragile. not sure if it would be an easy implementation tho
I feel that the dripstone block could use the same random rotation effect that other "terrain blocks" have (like regular stone), as the texture feels very repetitive.
The one thing I really want is to make Dripstone (and the stalactites, stalagmites) renewable, as it's such a nice decorative block, that can also be used for renewable lava!
Granite more common in dripstone: Hello, so for the dripstone cave I was thinking perhaps a nice gradient of dripstones and granite since both share similar colours and may go well with each other.
A cool use for dripstone could be that if it drips on a copper block it will weather faster
There should be a mob that spawns only in Dripstone caves. Maybe some sort of rock monster with spikes like the stalagmites/tites that can camouflage in with the rocks.

I can't comment on the biome's difficulty yet, but I think there needs to be more of a draw to it. It could be really interesting for Iron ore to be more abundant here, and maybe Creepers spawn a bit more frequently too.
I posted on t his, but comparator output should vary depending on how many Pointed dripstone a dripstone bloc kor pointed dripstone segment is supporting

I like geology, and I think that if there is lava above the block on which the stalagtite is going down, and if there isn't a cauldron, it should create basalt under it. If it's water above, it should create calcite under it. About the filling rate of cauldrons it should be fast, if there is an aquifer / lava chamber above the stalagtite, it makes sense that the fluids infiltrate quite easily through the stones and go down rapidly into the cauldron. If it isn't already the case, there should be water and lava droplets on the stalagtites, you see like water droplets on a wet sponge block.

I feel that the texture for the dripstone block is a wee bit too rough, and therefore not as good for building as it could be.

PS I'm referring to the block itself, not the stalagmites.
Stalagmites should randomly fall. It would be a nice avoid and take cover mechanic.
I think that instead of making the dripstone drip slower so as to make infinite lava impractical, make it drain the fluid above.

Reiterating on the suggestion for renewable dripstone when a cauldron isn't present, maybe the stalactite has to be the "waterlogged" variant, and the resulting stalagmite would only be created on Dripstone Blocks? That way players have some control over whether more dripstone is created or not, as well as being thematic and (somewhat) educational to how they're formed in real life.

Currently, the damage is less unbalanced than the infrequency of pointed dripstone spawning. The clusters that they spawn in when you play a single biome world are very easy to avoid and don't pose much of a threat. The damage doesn't matter if you never take any.
Hola cuando va a salir minecraft 1.17

I second HeliusEagleClaws comment about making dripstone create calcite. Id be fine with just calcite since basalt is renewable already. Maybe Tuff?

Please, do NOT make pointed dripstone 3D lol, it looks awesome as it is. I do have to agree with it not blending in however. Unless dripstone caves are going to be lined with the blocks, I would prefer to see variants of pointed dripstone that match the stone type it is growing out of. At least just stone stalagmites and stalactites. Perhaps we could craft pointed dripstone out of stone type blocks, allowing us to terraform as we see fit, so you dont have to program them into the generation? I know Id love to see blackstone ones for the nether.

I would decrease the cauldron fill time too, I really dont see the harm in being able to gather lots of obsidian or having a good source of fuel for a furnace, it all takes work to set up anyway. Players are going to need their coal for spelunking now so itll be great to have a robust fuel source available.

I also second adding dripstone to underwater caves, it would look SO good in an already incredible update.
make it the first lavaloggable block and have them generate poking out of lava lakes i simply think it would b cool

Dripstone should fall down randomly. As lush caves are meant to be more friendly due to it's vegetation, dripstone should meant danger due to it's spikes. There is no danger in dripstone caves, dripstone is more decorations than real spikes, this should change. 1/50 (this is arguable) dripstones which are less than 5 block near to the x and z coords of the player, should fell down. This would be an amazing challenge because player will be trying to get materials and pay attention if there is a dripstone which could smash his head!

Pointed dripstone should be waterloggeable to avoid drown-cheesing like you can already do with doors which I believe is also being fixed. Therefore not taking away from blocks that are intended to help with that
The dripstone point things emmit darkness on bedrock
Powder snow should work the same way as water and lava on dripstone. Just for a game mechanic to make this easier to obtain.

Dripstone bricks, tiles, walls, stairs, slabs, and everything else?

I'm mostly saying this because it's the only type of stone (or even block) with the type of brown that it has.  I think it would be a very good building block so please add it.

Does pointed dripstone grow (i.e. is it renewable?)

If not, it really should be!
I think dripstone should be dangerous when it falls and it should sometimes  fall when players are under it.

The Dripstone Caves are pretty underwhelming. It is extremely unlikely that stalactites will fall on the player or that the player will fall onto stalagmites while exploring, as the only things that seem to affect them are creeper explosions or the player's own doings. They don't force the player to think differently when traversing them.

For example, if they were affected by projectiles or if there were pits filled with stalagmites scattered about the Dripstone Caves, the player would be forced to think about how to best avoid them.
"Should I build over them? What if a mob knocks me in?"
"Should I knock down the stalactites with my own projectiles first?"
"Should I hug the wall?"
Drip stone should make dripping noises and the noise should echo when in a cave
the mason villager should sell dripstone or dripstone blocks

Maybe there could be a "Pointed Stone" or "Pointed Deepslate" That generates very rarely in the biome, and works the same as regular, except maybe Pointed Deepslate deals more damage?

 

Also maybe Pointed Deepslate could make a Spiked Piston.

I am very very pleased the team is taking Minecrafts design philosophy in new directions. A lot of nostalgia addicts dont like the new Pointed Dripstone but I feel it is a welcome change to non block items. Plants not being a cube is why people love them in their builds so much. These new items break up the rigidity and symmetry of the caves and gives them a richer texture as you explore them. They also provide us with renewable water and lava, theyre amazing to say the least. I dont know how you would do it, but I would LOVE to see some variations of the Pointed Dripstone shapes. Long, thin ones and fat stout ones. Smaller thin ones would look great in smaller, narrower caves and the stout ones would fit in the large caverns and dripstone biome, to kind of break up the repetition. Ive wanted these since i started playing in 2013 and im so close now lol. Maybe they could spread from a growing stalagmite/stalactite as an incidental thing, and they stay when you break the main Pointed Dripstone? And the stout ones can be formed by clustering Pointed Dripstone in certain configurations (2x2, 1x2)?

Pointed Dripstone placed under ice should drip water when in the nether.

The nether would still be more or less water starved, but it would mean players that choose to live in the nether long term would be able to brew potions without needing to go to the overworld.
I just want to say that make another variation for them. Maybe a stone like textures, hehehe.
Dripstones should be included in the crafting recipe for the ligtning rod, so that it incourages players to explore more caves

They're beautiful! A rare, larger variant would be amazing. Perhaps large caves can rarely generate with crystals and amethyst blocks on their walls. Exploring these crystal caves would be amazing!

A method to create renewable calcite would be great! Renewability is very important in Minecraft worlds, especially console editions, even more so in multiplayer.

Copper and amethyst should have more uses. Perhaps to craft a chest that emits high light level?
geodes are now to rare and spawn in groups
I absolutely love them. Like gaspoweredpick said though, they're way too common. I flew around underground in spectator and saw at least ten.
The outer layer of amethyst geodes above the height y=0 should consist of tuff, and the outer layer of amethyst geodes below the height y=0 should consist of smooth basalt.

Amethyst needs way more uses. I can honestly players seeking out the geodes just to get calcite. Some ideas I had are:

Black Light that stops mobs from spawning without giving off actual light so you can make dark builds without creepers blowing it up.

Additional Status buffs on beacons by using amethyst blocks in the base like night vision or being able to change weather/time.

Crystal Knives/Daggers that can be thrown and not Enchanted as a late-game projectile.

The only thing amethyst has going for it right now is the best incredibly obscure tinted glass, which isn't that useful.
amethyst tools and armor, slightly better than netherite, full set of armor: gives speed effect in caves. crafte like regular armor but with diamonds/emeralds in the middlle.

Another use for amethyst could be jewelled armour. The gems would help individualize player armour. Crafting this armour could be another use for the blacksmith table.

It would consist of small gemstones in fixed places on any of the metal or diamond armours. Geodes could be expanded to include various colours for ruby, topaz, etc. Providing even more incentive to find these rare structures as a wearable status symbol.

Here are my thoughts about the geodes:

-The 21w19a geode distribution feels much more balanced; it's now truly special to find one. 

-Smooth basalt, calcite, and amethyst are all great, but they need more variants to be the staples in building that they should be. Calcite should get stairs, slabs, and walls; and there should be a brick variant of these as well. Smooth basalt would look nice with stair, slab, wall, and brick variants, but since it's not unique to geodes that isn't as important. Finally, regular amethyst should have slab and stair variants. It should have a smooth variant (with slabs and stairs), and a smooth bricks variant (also with slabs and stairs). An amethyst column or chiseled amethyst block would also be great.

-I love the idea of incredibly rare geodes that are five or six times the size. They would make for an incredible find.

-Calcite, being both the most-sought-after and hardest-to-find block of the update, should get a crafting recipe. I think a recipe similar to diorite's, with amethyst shards replacing the quartz, would be nice.

-Naturally, amethyst needs more crafting recipes, but I'd expect those would come later down the road, and I'm fine with that.

Feedback:

The Amethyst Geodes and Blocks are well made and can come up in various creativities.

However on a personal opinion, the uses of Amethyst is rather limited, only making more Amethyst blocks, a Spyglass and some Tinted Glass which that is it.

Suggestions:

  • Using Tinted Glass on a beacon makes the beam 50% more transparant.
  • The ability for them to be used to repair any tool in an Anvil but only 33% as much as using the tool's original material. (E.g, Diamond Sword uses Diamond, using an Amethyst Crystal will only repair it 33% compared to a diamond)

I'm sure many people here have said this long before I did, but amethyst items definitely need more uses than just the spyglasses and tinted glass. For as common and as nearly limitless as they are, they really only serve to fill up inventory space.

Here are some of my suggestions to improve the usability of amethyst:

- A Laser. Not the *pew-pew* kind, but the kind of lasers that act like tripwires or can relay redstone signals and can be used over very long distances with no delay to them. This may be a late-game item you'd craft using quartz / prismarine, redstone, and of course amethyst.

- Crafting together diamonds, emeralds, and amethyst shards with gold nuggets all across the top can make Jewelry which can be sold to villagers for a hefty return of emeralds.

- Like DarkStalkerMoon mentioned, Crystal Daggers/Knives would be an interesting use for amethyst shards. It would also be neat if these daggers/knives can be tipped with certain potion effects like arrows are. Maybe have this feature available only at the fletching table...?

- Maybe generate Cave Villages under mountains that can trade amethyst for emeralds and whatnot. Or, maybe, add a new villager profession "The Prospector" that can trade amethyst and other mining related items for emeralds.

The list can go on and on, but there can be a multitude of uses for amethyst other than what's already there.

I personally think amethyst is useless at the moment. I think some better uses such as armor, weapons, modifications to items, and more uses similar to those would make them seem better. I also think we need a goblin village/camp where there is a goblin leader and different types of goblins such as archer goblins, spear goblins, and goblins that sit at towers defending there village would be cool. I get we are getting The Warden but I feel that you don't gain anything from killing it. Anytime I kill a boss I want some use to the item it drops but The Warden has no purpose in killing it. I also feel that part 1 of Caves and Cliffs has an hour of new content until you run out of things to do and make. I don't want to be running around in caves with no purpose. I want to be running around in caves to see new structures and new ores for armor. You might tell me to go play mods but I shouldn't have to go download a mod just so I can get better armor.
I think adding a large amount of amethyst crystals to a weapon or armor can make that item better or stronger.

Here's my criticism of the item: Amethyst is borderline useless. It's incredibly niché, I doubt people are going to find a geode and be like "Woow a super rare geod, now I can make cool black glass". Here are just some random ideas of what I would do with Amethyst:

A redstone component that reacts depending on the weather?

What about an Amethyst crystal block that will absorb the light level that it is exposed to forever? (similar to how magma blocks once worked)

What about a potion made from amethyst power (formed when an anvil drops on an amethyst block) that can give the player an "amethystic" aura ability to scare off light intolerant mobs? (Like zombies)

What about being able to add some Amythests to boots with the Smithing table, which would grant those boots 1 (and only 1) safe fall from any height, the addon would break after and the player would have to add it again. It doesn't make SENSE but it gives the item some use that inspired enthusiasm and excitement when we find a geode.

 

Amethyst is a crystal, so much what it could do might be related to light, and obviously the suggestions above are just random ideas that I put 10 seconds of thought into so please don't assume these are serious suggestions, just ideas, intrinsic reasons to be excited when you find a geode, giving it uses and making it worth the dangerous trip of finding them.
Amethyst could be used to make a special block that detects and gives off a redstone signal based on light level.

Amethyst has no use in the game and should contribute to one of Minecraft's core mechanics so players would want to go out and mine it. This would make ice biome bases so much more fun! Having to incorporate some sort of heat into it would definitely add depth to the game!

Just to be clear, freezing kills by gradually reducing the player's capacity to hold HP. If the ice reaches the red hearts, it can still freeze right over it, so in some cases it will decrease remaining HP along with max HP (if there was any confusion about the title).

When you have 8 hearts frozen, you are much more vulnerable to dying because you can't have more than 4 HP, but you can take action to warm up and eventually recover. The cold itself won't kill you until 10 hearts of ice damage is accumulated. At that point, your max HP reaches 0 and you've lost all capacity to hold HP. If you have Absorption hearts left, those will start depleting and you die when its all gone.

That way, you can't instantly freeze to death because you were on 1 HP. To freeze to death, the cold has to turn enough hearts to ice that you don't have any left to live.

Good suggestion overall, but the freezing hearts texture you've made should be hardcore only and regular difficulty freezing hearts should be untextured plain ice blue to keep with the special texture of hardcore hearts.

Not a bad idea . . . a flying overworld mob seemed great but people were already skipping the night more often than not and we needed some incentive to go out and adventure rather than sleeping. What we got was the phantom to punish us for not going to bed on time.

Honestly, I think that beds and phantoms have a lot of intrinsic problems that arise from two common but totally differing gameplay styles--half the players want the challenge of surviving the night, half the players want to skip it so they can focus on building and resource gathering without constant interruptions. I think phantoms sort of occupy a worst of both worlds, harshly punishing the former half and making the latter half even more desperate.

I think this change would make phantoms much more interesting, and would encourage "dogfights" and other high-elevation open-air phantom combats, which are very fun, while cutting back on phantoms getting stuck on trees and roofs while you obliviously gather logs for your next build.

Given how large these caves are going to be in 1.18, it would make sense to have an alternative lighting option that would be reliable for players that want to do some mining. These caves, except the ones filled with lava or the Lush caves, will be extremely dark even with your gamma settings turned up to the maximum. This idea wouldn't remove the need for torches or any other light source as lighting up an area with these blocks to prevent mob spawning would still be a must. A Miner's Helmet would just help players to see in relatively dark places. The recipe at the minimum should be comprised of a lantern + an iron helmet.
This needs to happen as it will be so crucial with the massive caves.
It would work best for the original layer of bedrock a 0 to also be completely replaced by deepslate!
The original bedrock layer should be replaced by deepslate, and everything below it until -64 to also be turned into deepslate.
y tho. Bees don't live underground like that

Since we have flowering azelia, this is already a sensible change. Finding bees underground within the lush caves would really make it feel more alive.

And also many species of bees do in fact create nests within the ground, so it is very plausible.

With how prevalent mushrooms are in Minecraft, I feel like an underground mushroom cave biome is almost a necessity for this update. This is something that I think is extremely logical and would fit vanilla minecraft very well! They would be a nice rare encounter, allowing you to have a brief respite from the mobs in the caves, and allowing you to gather some mushroom stew if you are running low on food!
We need this in minecraft
Shroomlight could also generate along with a few more lighting mushrooms, when I think of mushroom caves I think of all these unique lights!
I was hoping for a cave biome like this. I hope it gets added because it just makes sense. A new mushroom variant would be awesome.
